security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown documentation about the pixi package manager. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, no command execution capabilities. Risk factor evidence array is empty due to lack of any executable components.

content.value_statement: Complex scientific Python dependencies slow down research. Pixi unifies conda and PyPI ecosystems with fast dependency resolution, reproducible lockfiles, and seamless environment management for scientific computing projects.
actual_capabilities: Create reproducible Python environments with unified conda and PyPI support
Configure feature-based environments for dev, test, prod, and GPU workflows
Define automated tasks for scientific pipelines and testing
Generate cross-platform lockfiles for team collaboration
Migrate existing conda or requirements.txt projects to pixi
Integrate with CI/CD systems for automated testing
limitations: Pixi must be installed separately on the target system
Cannot execute shell commands directly - provides documentation only
Does not manage environments directly - user must run pixi commands
Only provides guidance; actual package installation requires pixi CLI

prompt_templates.title: Setup Project
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I set up a new scientific Python project with pixi? Show me how to initialize the project, add numpy and pandas, and create a dev environment with testing tools.

prompt_templates.title: Add Dependencies
prompt_templates.prompt: What is the correct way to add scientific packages to my pixi project? I need NumPy from conda-forge and a custom private package from PyPI.

prompt_templates.title: Create Environment
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me configure a pixi project with three environments: default for production, dev with Jupyter and ruff, and test with pytest. Show me the pyproject.toml configuration.

prompt_templates.title: Build Pipeline
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a pixi task workflow that runs: download data, clean data, train model, and evaluate results. Show task dependencies and how to run the complete pipeline.

output_examples.input: How do I create a pixi project with GPU support for machine learning?
output: Initialize project: pixi init ml-project --format pyproject
Add base dependencies: pixi add python=3.11 numpy pandas scikit-learn
Create GPU feature: pixi add --feature gpu pytorch-cuda=11.8 -c pytorch -c nvidia
Configure environments in pyproject.toml with gpu feature
Run with GPU: pixi run --environment gpu python train.py

best_practices: Use `pixi init --format pyproject` for new projects to leverage standard Python packaging
Pin exact versions in dependencies when creating reproducible research environments
Commit pixi.lock to version control so all team members get identical environments
anti_patterns: Mixing system packages with conda packages - let pixi manage all dependencies
Using loose version constraints without understanding update implications
Skipping lockfile commits - leads to environment drift across team members

faq.question: Is pixi faster than conda?
faq.answer: Yes, pixi uses the Rust-based rattler resolver and performs parallel downloads, making it 10-100x faster than traditional conda for dependency resolution.

faq.question: Can I use both conda-forge and PyPI packages together?
faq.answer: Yes, pixi seamlessly integrates both sources. Use `pixi add numpy` for conda packages and `pixi add --pypi package` for PyPI packages in the same project.

faq.question: How does pixi ensure reproducibility?
faq.answer: Pixi generates a pixi.lock file that includes exact versions and checksums for all packages across platforms. Commit this file to guarantee identical environments.

faq.question: Does this skill install pixi?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides documentation and guidance. Users must install pixi separately from https://pixi.sh or via their system's package manager.

faq.question: Can I migrate from conda environment.yml to pixi?
faq.answer: Yes, use `pixi init --format pyproject --import-environment environment.yml` to convert existing conda environments to pixi format.

faq.question: When should I choose pixi over uv?
faq.answer: Choose pixi when you need compiled scientific libraries (NumPy, SciPy, GDAL), multi-language support (R, Julia, C++), or cross-platform reproducibility with lockfiles.
